fields.description:
Quite often, when going through a list of issues, we observe the following behaviour. We select a filter, e. g. one that displays open issues to be discussed, then click on the first issue. Suppose that the filter shows, say, 23 issues. Often, iterating through the issues using the _Next_ button in the upper right corner (for Jira 4.0, and using the down arrow for Jira 4.1) stops before the last issue, e. g., at some point it displays, say, "Issue 19/19", and the _Next_ link is disabled. However, when we click the _Return to search_ link, the missing issues are there.

This is quite a concern, because it can lead to issues being "forgotten" if one does not remember to click the _Return to search_ link.
fields.summary: Iterating through search results using Next does not always lead to the last issue

fields.description:
If JIRA is run in OpenJDK (JAVA_HOME) charts generated by the application are broken.

!JIRA-Graph.png!

The labelling/fonts on the x and y axis does not appear correctly and the axis runs out of range.
fields.summary: Charts are displayed with unreadable font when OpenJDK is used

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-21680].
  {panel}

Currently [Supported Platforms|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Supported+Platforms] doesn't list of any vendors of JDK that we support/test our application with.

Based on our bad experience with the IBM's JDK [JRA-19379|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-19379] we should test OpenJDK and update our documentation accordingly.

OpenJDK becomes more popular due to its availability in linux editions. It would be worth giving some guidelines to our customers to help them avoid possible disappointments.  

FYI. Confluence according to the [Supported Platforms page|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Supported+Platforms] supports only Sun JDK.
fields.summary: Test compatibility between JIRA and OpenJDK

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-21679].
  {panel}

Instead of being completely controlled by Global Permissions, the sharing of filters and dashboards could be controlled by a combination of permissions.  This approach would provide some level of filter/dash sharing privileges to all users:

* Share with project (ALL) - restricted to project admins (or controlled by new permission in the permission schemes) (anyone with global permission also can share at this level)
* Share with project (by role) AND Share with group - user allowed to only share with roles to which they belong (implicit permission - no special permission, but add system parameter to turn feature on/off) (anyone with global permission also can share at this level)
* Share with everyone - restricted to global permission only

This approach would allow administrators of larger implementations to have more granular control over how users share filters without restricting users to not be able to collaborate.  All the while, the current behavior can still be achieved by using the global permission.  Whereas, today, it's an all-or-none approach.

This item dovetails with JRA-9997 and JRA-19780.
fields.summary: Security Flexibility for Filter & Dashboard Sharing

fields.description: Create a project and assign permission scheme that does not grant the 'browse project' permission to the current user (even though the current user is a system or JIRA admin) and the project is created, but not all options are selected.  Alternatively, selecting no permission scheme has the same result.  This also occurs when editing some fields (i.e. avatar) on existing projects.  The JIRA or System Admins should be able to create or edit project details (title, url, description, avatar, etc) without needing explicit project browse permission.
fields.summary: Creating or Editing Project by System or JIRA Administrator should always work

fields.description:
Based on the way we manage releases, it would be nice if the "unreleased versions" in any version picker would display by the due date (ascending date order 'today' to null).  And the "released versions" should display by version number.  This could be a system parameter - 'by version list order' or 'by date/version order'

This item relates to the displaying of versions discussed in JRA-21676 and JRA-19741.  For reference, our version list is attached in JRA-19741.
fields.summary: Sort Version Pickers differently

fields.description:
Due to limitations introduced by the new 'versions due' summary (refer to JRA-19741), we have had to reorganize our version list.  This now causes the versions to be out of order in the 'road map' and 'change log' summary screens (see attached).

A possible option would be introduction of sort order in both of these screens by either Version or Due Date (or both).  And, if sorting is enabled, then an option for system default.  Or, simply addressing the item discussed in JRA-19741 would allow us to put our version list back in the correct order and this anomaly will resolve naturally except for the fact that we would like to see the native behavior to be:

* Road Map sorted by due date 
* Change Log sorted by version.

I am attaching the Road Map screenshot that shows the versions out of order.  For reference, our complete version list is attached to JRA-19741.
fields.summary: Add sort capabililty in the Road Map and Change Log screens
Bug in ParametersUtils

fields.description: "Unresolved: By Version issues report" shows a wrong number of Unscheduled issues even after a reindexing.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-21671].
  {panel}

JIRA cannot currently be deployed in a hosted Tomcat environment :
# It implies the declaration of a JNDI resource for database access
# It implies a modification to the default Tomcat security policy
# It implies the modification of shared server libs

While the first two points can be understandable, the third one is a showstopper - as in a hosted environment, such modifications can affect other web applications deployed on the same server instance.

NOTE : This request as originally a JIRA support request [JSP-57058|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-57058]
fields.summary: Make JIRA deployable in a hosted environment

fields.description: Starting with Version 4.1.2 plugins that use webwork actions that implement PrepareAction are no longer properly initialized by calling their prepare() method.
fields.summary: Upgrading to Jira 4.1.2 breaks PrepareAction functionality in plugins

fields.description: Our character encoding is set to ISO-8859-1. When a comment is added, it is saved and displayed correctly in ISO-8859-1. But if the comment is previewed before saving it, on the preview field it is apparently shown as UTF-8, which means that it looks pretty ugly, because the Content-Type of the page is set to ISO-8859-1.
fields.summary: Character encoding problem when previewing a comment

fields.description:
The initial symptom is that the buttons and links in the tool bar fail to respond.
However, if I view another tab and switch back, the section that _should_ be covered by toolbar is not redrawn, and continues to show whatever was on that part of the other tab's screenful.

It's possible to fix this by force-reloading several times, but this has to be done each time the problem recurs.
fields.summary: Toolbar at top of screen fails to respond

fields.description:
We use JIRA for our call center and support help desk.  The Announcement Banner is used to keep all support personnel informed of known outages or widespread issues.  Unfortunately, permission to edit/change the Announcement Banner is bundled with the permissions inferred by being a JIRA Administrator.  There is not a way to allow someone to change the announcement banner without making them a JIRA Administrator.

We'd like to be able to grant this permission independent of the JIRA Administrator role.
fields.summary: Ability to grant permission to modify Announcement Banner

fields.description:
For example, if you have a Start Date custom field of Date Time type and the user enters...

* 30/Jun/10 300:43 PM it accepts the time and moves the date onto 13 Jul.

* 30/Jun/10 17:43 PM instead of 30/Jun/10 05:43 PM it accepts the time and moves the date onto the following day.
fields.summary: Date Time custom field type allows invalid time formats
Make the "Web Resources Plugin" either system or bundled

fields.description:
Allow users to have the ability to manage versions without being a project administrator, by adding the proper permission in the permission scheme.

For some users, is valuable to let the engineers create new versions without actually being project administrators.
fields.summary: Add the ability to manage versions without being a project administrator

fields.description:
I was running tests on JIRA with ~1 000 000 issues, where index optimization time started to be non-trivial (in minutes)

It turned out that when the _jira.index.max.reindexes_ limit got exceeded the index optimization operation was started for every change even though index optimization was already started (and not finished) by the previous change.

As a result I ended up with 34 concurrent index optimizations (taking 2 hours to finish), which totally saturated JIRA.

Workaround - set _jira.index.max.reindexes_ to 0 and rely on nightly optimization.

What it should look like: don't schedule index optimization if one is already in progress.
fields.summary: Index optimization is triggered for every change above 4000 even when an optimization is already in progress
Heirarchical User Stories/Issues

fields.description: Looks like the icons for ordering the sub-tasks not showing up in IE 7.x. I have attached two screenshot for IE version and the problem from the issue. Seems this isn't holding up any progress. Firefox 3.6 & IE 8.x are ok.
fields.summary: Subtask order icons not showing up in IE 7.x

fields.description:
I am testing the upgrade from JIRA 3.13.2 to 4.1.2 and I noticed that the [Saved Fitler with columns plugin|https://studio.plugins.atlassian.com/wiki/display/FLTR/JIRA+Saved+Filter+with+Columns+Plugin] is no longer free. JIRA itself now includes the 'Filter Results' gadget which provides almost the same functionality, exept that I cannot choose the order in which the fields are displayed.

This is extremely annoying as I cannot have my same useful dashboard like before. Please also add the functionality to choose the order of the columns (I think they are now alphabetical?)
fields.summary: Allow column ordering in the 'Filter Results' gadget

fields.description:
Migrated from Jira 3.12.2 to Jira 4.1.1, then deleted some projects. Then got the following from an (admin) user:
I have filters on my Dashboard that show my Opened, In Progress, and Approved issues.  Those filters are showing me the following error:
There are problems with the current configuration for this gadget. The errors below may have been caused by the deletion of entities required by the gadget or by changes to your permissions.
•	The selected filter filter-13405 has an error: The value 'PMOR' does not exist for the field 'project'..
•	The selected filter filter-13405 has an error: The value 'XPR' does not exist for the field 'project'..
I get the same error for filters 13450 and 13451.   When I try to fix then (delete the projects that give an error) I get this error:

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-21644].
  {panel}

Recently got the 4.1.x 'new look' 'view issue' and 'edit issue' screens via JIRA Studio. I see much prior discussion, but no prior issue focused on one specific aspect: the fixed-at-top issue title and operations bar. On screens with more spare width than height -- and many laptop widescreens fall into this category -- this behavior severely cramps the interesting discussion log. 

In particular, the fixed-area can take up more than half the viewport (!), with just a few assumptions (which happen to apply on my 13" MacBook, and probably others' laptops as well). Fonts may be generously sized for the small screen -- making a long issue title wrap to 3-4 lines, and the operations tabs wrap to 2 lines  -- and other toolbars/menubars/docks/tab-bars/search-footers further cramp the viewport from top and bottom. This makes very few lines of comment logs visible. 

The old layout used horizontal space more effectively, such that the entire vertical viewport could be used to view the comment-log. 

At least in the current generations of Firefox (3.x) and Safari (5.x), fixating the issue title inside the page is largely redundant, because it already appears in the window title bar. (Further, this info does not need to be repeatedly consulted while browsing an issue's history.) Easy access to operations (especially the most-used 'comment' button) could be provided at top and bottom without impairing the reading of long issue histories. 

I know you don't want to provide an 'old look' toggle; however, simply allowing a toggle (or CSS customization) to disabl the fixed-float of the title/operations-bar would fix 90%+ of this problem on small/wide screens.
fields.summary: allow title/operations-bar to scroll off top -- big benefit for small/wide screens; can be optional

fields.description:
Many issue tracking systems get a lot of duplicate issues, and unless those triaging the incoming queue have very good memories (and/or search tools), these duplicates can lead to confusing responses to each issue, and possibly even conflicting fixes for each of them.

To help mitigate this, JIRA should automatically try to find any related issues already in the system for the issue being created, and encourage the user to add details to an existing issue instead of creating a new one. This could be displayed as "Did you mean ...?" prompts, or as a click through page, or some other solution.

Any duplicate search tools could also run any time the issue description is reworded using more common product or domain terms, to make it easier to close the (now-duplicate) issue.

Doing this search automatically as part of issue creation will make reporting issues (and collecting votes on those issues, where applicable) easier and more streamlined for everyone involved as compared to expecting users to carry out this search manually before reaching for the "create issue" hammer or more likely forcing the triage team to do these lookups themselves.
fields.summary: Automatically search for existing related issues when creating new issues

fields.description:
When jira and tomcat are deployed in the same container jira should not assume bamboo being available during the application startup phase.

Tomcat brings applications up serially in non-deterministic order, and while it is starting, when it receives a request, it simply blocks. So, the first app started coming up, makes a call on the second, which blocks, and Tomcat never tries to bring the second up because the first one doesn't finish coming up because it's waiting for the second to come up. This is more of an application problem though, the fact is, nothing should ever make a remote call during start up, otherwise this will wreak havoc with circular dependencies. At very least, any remote calls made should have a short timeout (10s).
fields.summary: JIRA and Bamboo startup fail when deployed together in one tomcat container

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-21594].
  {panel}

The group browser admin screen in JIRA does not provide any feedback when a group has been successfully added.

----------------------

This was the sequence of operations performed by one of the Studio devs:

1) Log in and set "Remember Me".
2) Go the Group Browser in JIRA.
3) Wait for a session timeout (or manually invalidate the XSRF token).
4) Add a new group.
5) Click "Retry Operation" on the XSRF error screen.

In this case, the user was not aware that the group had been sucessfully added (because there was no feedback saying so), and attempted to add the group again, this time seeing an error message.

Given that it's not obvious to the user what happens after an XSRF timeout, a simple "You have successfully created group <name>" message would make it clear to the user that the operation did take place.

This is different from most forms in JIRA because the form submits back to itself - it's not clear whether the form has been submitted or not.
fields.summary: No user feedback on successful group creation

fields.summary: The strings "Gadget hinzufügen", "FishEye-Konfiguration", "Perforce-Auftragsintegration" are in german but should be in english

fields.description: Here are the 2 patches that gives this problem: - http://downloads.atlassian.com/software/jira/downloads/patch/patch-JRA-21004-3.13.4.zip - http://downloads.atlassian.com/software/jira/downloads/patch/patch-JRA-21004-3.13.5.zip After applying the patch, here are the steps to reproduce this problem: # Open any IE browser and log into JIRA # Go to _Administration -> Users, Groups & Roles -> Project Role Browser_ # Click on any +Manage Default Members+ # Click on +Edit+ under 'Default Groups' # Click on the Group Picker icon # You will hit into the following syntax error: {noformat} Webpage error details User Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Windows NT 5.1; Trident/4.0; Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 6.0; Windows NT 5.1; SV1) ; .NET CLR 1.1.4322; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; OfficeLiveConnector.1.3; OfficeLivePatch.0.0; .NET CLR 3.0.4506.2152; .NET CLR 3.5.30729) Timestamp: Fri, 18 Jun 2010 13:44:09 UTC Message: Syntax error Line: 585 Char: 1 Code: 0 URI: http://localhost:8100/secure/popups/GroupPickerBrowser.jspa?formName=startform&multiSelect=true&element=groupNames Message: Syntax error Line: 647 Char: 1 Code: 0 URI: http://localhost:8100/secure/popups/GroupPickerBrowser.jspa?formName=startform&multiSelect=true&element=groupNames {noformat} After viewing at the page source, it seems that the following line is causing this syntax error: {noformat} (document.getElementById('openElement').firstChild.nodeValue.replace(/\s/g, ""))"> {noformat} The weird thing is that I have tried applying the security patches from JIRA 3.12 until JIRA 4.0 and only *JIRA 3.13.4 and JIRA 3.13.5* that gets this syntax error in IE.
fields.summary: grouppicker.jsp in the JIRA 3.13.4 and 3.13.5 security patch throws a syntax error in IE browser

fields.description:
When searching for a custom field configured to show up for only bug types the JQL will recommend the custom field name, but after entering the equality and space it does not recommend the possible values.

In our case the custom field is a multi select, so it should show the multi select values.
fields.summary: Custom Fields with specific contexts are non populated in JQL

fields.description:
When using the simple search tool selecting one of the special fix version options (Unreleased Versions, Released Versions) causes the simple search to be too complex.

This is causing existing searches in 3.1.x to be considered complex JQL queries after an upgrade.
fields.summary: SimpleSearch turns Complex when searching on Fix Version options

fields.description:
In new indexing mechanism all 4 different independent(!) indexes cannot be commited (flushed) simultaneously.
It could cause performance degradation on big amount of updates.

Explanation of this behaviour is in com.atlassian.jira.index.DefaultIndexEngine.FlushPolicy. Method perform is synchronised on static enum instance which shared across all index writers. There should be another lock used index type (issues, comments etc) based.
fields.summary: Different indexes cannot be commited at same time

fields.description: When loading a dashboard, there are several AJAX page loads fired off in the background, but there is no obvious sign that requests have been sent, or how much more is left to load. On a slightly customized dashboard, a slow link, or a heavily loaded JIRA server, the delay between loading the (empty) dashboard and it finally finishing populating all the gadgets is quite noticeable and can be off-putting. It would be nice to show an overall page load status and included at least a rough estimate of how many more requests are left to load.
fields.summary: Show overall page load progress for dashboard

fields.description:
This cache invalidation triggered on any «Issue created» operation, and cause full reread of two tables and all node association of type Project to Project Category.

It's not so harmful, but refresh is syncchronized (which cause serious performance issues when i simultaneously create two Issues)!! Why? To avoid two concurrent cache filling? But reading from cache is still possible even it contains non actual data.

More correct behavior is to invalidate only specific elements of cache and remove it from cache and then reread only one from DB. It could be realized with ConcurentHashMap to avoid locking of actions on different projects
fields.summary: ProjectCache is another performance bottleneck under load

fields.summary: Index Out of Bounds exception when editing dashboard

fields.description:
hello,

   I defined a workflow, indicating the "resolve issue" transition only allows assignee to perform, and this transition has a postfunction as "Assign the issue to the lead developer". 

    The project lead created one issue, later, I found that it did work when the original assignee changed the resolution status, It shows the current reporter and asignee are both the project lead in the issue infomation page. However, the project lead can't see this change in his "assigned to me" in system dashboard.

    Could you give me any help of it? I do need this alter function.

    Thanks.
fields.summary: about the assignee

fields.description:
After the creation of an issue it is by default viewable by "All Users".

It is not possible to change the value after re-editing that issue.

After changing it and clicking the "Update" button, the viewable by entry stays "All Users"
fields.summary: Can not UPDATE the "Viewable By" field of an issue

fields.description:
When a user enters the ">" symbol in an issue description, it breaks the text and causes it to appear in the Operations sidebar. I've attached a screenshot of an example of this bug.

We have the Create and Link plugin installed (https://plugins.atlassian.com/plugin/details/4964). The text appears in the links it has added in the sidebar.
fields.summary: Description text showing up in Operations sidebar

fields.description:
The email address in CC is not added as Watcher when issue is commented via Email. This problem only occurred when user commenting on the issue and add email address to the CC in the email. Here are the steps to reproduce the problem:
# create a new service using [Create Or Comment handler|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Services#Services-CreateOrCommentHandler] with the "ccwatcher=true"
# write a new email, set the CC with a JIRA User's email and send it to the POP/IMAP server. The JIRA User will be added as Watcher to the new issue. 
# create another new issue via email or inside JIRA. Then, write a new email and set the CC with a JIRA User's email and set the newly created Issue Key in the Email's subject. The JIRA User will not be added as Watcher to the issue.
fields.summary: Create or Comment Handler will not add CC's email address as watcher if the issue already exist

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-21565].
  {panel}

Using colons in ID attributes conflicts with both CSS and JavaScript (particularly jQuery selectors). While there are workarounds involving escaping the colons it is generally considered bad practice.

Notable fields that are using colons are:
* File inputs (eg. attachment:1)
* Date pickers/date range fields (eg. customfield_10000:after)

Fixing these field IDs may break some existing plugins however.
fields.summary: Field IDs incorrectly using colons
AddProject validation fails to do everything it should

fields.description:
It sets a value against the wrong field. It also takes in parameters which are not as useful.

In light of recent improvements to the TimeTrackingSystemField, we should update this so that the IssueService is more useful for updating these fields.
fields.summary: IssueInputParameters setOriginalEstimate does not work as expected

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-21560].
  {panel}

This functionality has been disabled as a part of [JRA-21004|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-21004]. However, we should come up with a new implementation of the support request page in order to allow our customer to provide Support with their data.

There are quite a few customers using the request form to log tickets with us and disabling attachments on it has a negative impact on the quality of provided support (resolution time). Often during triaging we need to go back to customer and ask them to provide data that could be otherwise provided when they were originally reporting the issue.



I believe we were saying something similar in the past:

bq. NOTE: Not providing log files, environment information and backup may result in slower support service.
fields.summary: Reinstate ability to provide Support with backup and log file while submitting support request

fields.description:
Trying to get the project category name to use in various .vm files.  I have the following code in the priority-edit.vm and it works pefectly:

    #set ($projcat = $issue.getProjectObject().getProjectCategory())
    #set ($projcatname = $projcat.getString("name"))

Using the same exact code in the resolution-edit.vm fails to work.  It seems $projcat is undefined.  In testing, $proj = $issue.getProjectObject() returns the project code.  Not sure why it's failing to load the getProjectCategory() method.

I would expect the code to work in resolution-edit.vm as it does in priority-edit.vm.

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When a session contains a search result (as a result of using any search in JIRA), there is a possibility that during standard view issue operations a bottleneck can occur on the NextPreviousPager monitor. This can result in the entire JIRA becoming unresponsive and rendering the instance unusable.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

It is not currently known what the exact steps are to reproduce this, however it involves viewing issues when a search result is contained within a user session.

h3. Expected Results

JIRA operates as normal.

h3. Actual Results

JIRA becomes unresponsive as lock congestion occurs on the NextPreviousPager monitor.

h3. Notes
View issue screen is pretty fast (my measures points to 16 RPS), but only we have no active search. If the session contain a search request, updating NextPreviousPager is a significant bottleneck.
Even on 1 RPS response time raise exponentially and after 1 minute of load JIRA became unresponsive.

The performance impact can be exacerbated by using complicated searches or expensive JQL functions.

h3. Diagnosis

[Generate a Thread Dump|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Generating+a+Thread+Dump] 6 times every 10 seconds during periods of unresponsiveness and read it with [TDA|http://java.net/projects/tda] or a similar tool. If there is a bottleneck in the NextPreviousPager monitor as per the attached screenshot there is a significant likelihood the instance is affected by this problem.

This can also be identified with the below commands - we're going to grep the thread dumps to see how many threads that are waiting to lock NextPreviousPager. If there's a high number persisting across multiple thread dumps over time, it's probably this bug.

{noformat}
$ grep "waiting to lock.*NextPreviousPager" jstack.4440.threadHigh.* | awk '{print $1}' |sort |uniq -c
 24 jstack.4440.threadHigh.103649.939600529:
 27 jstack.4440.threadHigh.103701.620551473:
 25 jstack.4440.threadHigh.103713.178859435:
 25 jstack.4440.threadHigh.103724.736087099:
 25 jstack.4440.threadHigh.103736.376659166:
{noformat}

This shows the number of threads waiting to lock the monitor grouped by thread dump. In each thread dump that's 25+ which is a large number. Or read the threadies and check for larger numbers of this:

{noformat}
"http-bio-8080-exec-1479" daemon prio=10 tid=0x00007f3fe07ba800 nid=0x6d4f waiting for monitor entry [0x00007f3e7c581000]
 java.lang.Thread.State: BLOCKED (on object monitor)
 at com.atlassian.jira.issue.pager.NextPreviousPager.update(NextPreviousPager.java:151)
 - waiting to lock <0x00007f46331c6bc8> (a com.atlassian.jira.issue.pager.NextPreviousPager)
 at com.atlassian.jira.issue.pager.PagerManager.updatePager(PagerManager.java:41)
{noformat}
fields.summary: NextPreviousPager is bottleneck under highload
